stem: A 22-year-old male is 24 hours post-operative for a femur fracture repair. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: New onset of respiratory distress.
Background: Motor vehicle accident leading to comminuted femur fracture. Post-op Day 1.
Assessment: Client is increasingly confused and slightly agitated.
Recommendation: Rule out pulmonary complications.

tabs.title: Orthopedic & Skin Assessment
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingLocation
Neurovascular CheckPulses 2+; Warm; Sensation IntactRight foot (Surgical side)
RespiratoryTachypnea; CracklesBilaterally
Skin ObservationClusters of non-blanchable red spotsAcross Chest and Neck (Petechiae)
Mental StatusRestless; Disoriented to yearNeurological change

actionOptions.text: Apply high-flow oxygen via non-rebreather mask.
Maintain strict immobilization of the fractured limb.
Prepare the client for an immediate fasciotomy.

parameterOptions.text: Daily inspection of chest and neck for petechiae.
Distal pulse strength and capillary refill.

rationale.correct: The triad of FES (c2) is present: Respiratory distress (low SpO2), Neurological change (confusion), and a Petechial rash (chest/neck). Unlike Compartment Syndrome (where the limb is ischemic), the neurovascular checks in FES are usually normal. Actions focus on oxygenation (a1) and minimizing further fat release by stabilizing the bone (a2). Parameter monitoring focuses on the skin rash (p1) and oxygenation (p2).
clinicalPearls: Petechiae across the chest is the 'Pathognomonic' (classic) sign of Fat Embolism.
FES most commonly occurs with long bone (femur/pelvis) fractures within 24–72 hours.
Oxygen is the primary treatment; steroids are controversial and not standard NCLEX answers.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Fasciotomy is for Compartment Syndrome (pressure in the limb). FES is a systemic emergency that requires oxygen.
